repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Bank Restructuring and Debt
            Management Program Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Lessons emphasize the importance of
            government commitment to reform, which reinforced the strong
            ownership of the program, leading to its satisfactory
            implementation, and conducive to the preparation of the
            follow-up operation, as part of a programmatic phased
            approach. However, it is worth mentioning that this has been
            a high risk - though high reward as well - operation, and
            that difficulties are likely to arise. Also, the selection
            of at least two single-tranche programmatic loans, was key
            to restoring the operational relationship with Jamaica, and
            in ensuring a successful performance. The flexibility,
            promptness, and feasibility of compliance, allowed the
            Government to foresee attainable short-term objectives,
            which proved advantageous to both parties. Finally, given
            the risks involved, having an inter-institutional effort was
            useful, in that the Bank was able to stress unfavorable
            scenarios in the Government's program, and also
            leveraged from the work of the Inter American Development
            Bank on sectoral aspects of non-financial regulation.

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Bank Restructuring and Debt
            Management Program Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bank Restructuring and Debt
            Management Program Adjustment Loan Project, will support
            both the sale of one large bank, and the progress in
            restructuring two financial institutions. The operation will
            fund the retirement of part of the Financial Sector
            Adjustment Company Ltd. (FINSAC) bonds, and will complement
            other sources of funds, such as fiscal resources, proceeds
            from asset disposal, and loans from other international
            financial institutions. In addition, the Government will
            begin to service in cash, the remaining FINSAC bonds, held
            as assets in the intervened institutions. Furthermore,
            restructuring, and management of the public debt, arising
            from the resolution of the financial crisis, will be
            accomplished through an approved write-down in FINSAC debt;
            off-set of FINSAC bonds against Government deposits at the
            Bank of Jamaica (BOJ); and, by restructuring FINSAC bonds
            held by BOJ. These measures will allow a reduction in the
            outstanding stock of FINSAC debt, to be serviced in cash by
            April 2001. The project will also improve the coordination
            between bank and non-bank supervisory authorities, by
            committing an independent assessment of the Basle Core
            principles by mid 2001. Macroeconomic risks include higher
            than expected service debt burden, and failure to achieve
            fiscal stabilization, among others, though a re-assessment
            approach by the Bank will be considered, should conditions
            warrant it.
